items.title: Live: US and Europe will 'formalise' security guarantees for Ukraine within 10 days, Zelensky says
items.standfirst: The United States will help guarantee Ukraine's security in any deal to end Russia's war there, US President Donald Trump told President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday at the White House, though he stressed that European countries would be "a first line of defence". Zelensky said that the guarantees would be formalised on paper within 10 days. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: The United States will help guarantee Ukraine's security in any deal to end Russia's war there, US President Donald Trump told President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday at the White House, though he stressed that European countries would be "a first line of defence". Zelensky said that the guarantees would be formalised on paper within 10 days. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: Donning 'fabulous' outfit, Zelensky melds fashion and diplomacy
items.standfirst: Six months removed from the shocking dressing down he received at the hands of US President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky traded his trademark military-style garb for a sharp black suit for his high-stakes return to the White House on Monday, indulging Trump's perception of clothing choice as a mark of gratitude.
items.content: Six months removed from the shocking dressing down he received at the hands of US President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky traded his trademark military-style garb for a sharp black suit for his high-stakes return to the White House on Monday, indulging Trump's perception of clothing choice as a mark of gratitude.

items.title: Zelensky, European allies push for Ukraine ceasefire, security guarantees in high stakes DC summit
items.standfirst: Following a fruitless meeting between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his European allies at the White House on Monday, just hours after Russia launched a crushing attack in Ukraine. After Trump seemingly aligned with Putin, dropping threats of sanctions and his support for a ceasefire, Zelensky and his allies pushed back, emphasising the need for a pause in fighting and security guarantees for Ukraine in any potential peace deal.
items.content: Following a fruitless meeting between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his European allies at the White House on Monday, just hours after Russia launched a crushing attack in Ukraine. After Trump seemingly aligned with Putin, dropping threats of sanctions and his support for a ceasefire, Zelensky and his allies pushed back, emphasising the need for a pause in fighting and security guarantees for Ukraine in any potential peace deal.

items.standfirst: President Trump, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other European leaders came together at the White House on Monday to work out a possible way to end Russia's war in Ukraine. CBS News White House reporter Taurean Small has more.

items.title: Breaking down stakes of a possible trilateral meeting with Trump, Zelenskyy and Putin
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy returned to the White House to make his case on how to end Russia's war with his battle-weary country. Key European leaders were there, too. President Trump spoke to Russian President Vladimir Putin afterwards and said he's now making arrangements for a trilateral meeting between the two warring countries and himself. Charles Kupchan, senior fellow from the Council on Foreign Relations, joins to discuss.

Charles Kupchan, senior fellow from the Council on Foreign Relations, joins to discuss.

items.title: Trump, Zelenskyy, European leaders meet at White House
items.standfirst: President Trump and Ukraine’s President Zelenskyy held a White House meeting that was much warmer in tone then their showdown a few months ago. Trump said there does not need to be a ceasefire to move forward with a peace deal, while suggesting he would support security guarantees for Ukraine. NBC Nightly News anchor Tom Llamas reports.

items.title: Trump's endorsement of Kremlin lies 'problematic', researcher says
items.standfirst: FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks to Jaroslava Barbieri, Research Fellow at the Ukraine Forum of Chatham House, about the latest meeting between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. She says that Trump's endorsement of 'lies that the Kremlin has been consistently pushing' is problematic and that the 'dimension of justice as a key component for a durable peace in Ukraine is completely absent' from the talks.

items.title: Live: Zelensky arrives at White House for Ukraine ceasefire talks with Trump, European leaders
Zelensky urges Trump to bring 'peace through strength' against Russia
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.

items.title: Zelensky in Washington to discuss acceptable terms for peace deal
items.standfirst: Ukraine's future could hinge on a hastily assembled meeting Monday at the White House as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy brings with him an extraordinary cadre of European leaders to show U.S. President Donald Trump a united front against Russia. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondents in Ukraine and Brussels, Emmanuelle Chaze and Dave Keating.

items.title: Who will be at Zelensky's side for decisive talks with Trump on Ukraine-Russia war?
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Trump is arranging a meeting between Zelenskyy and Putin, according to reports.
• European leaders are pushing for the United States to guarantee Ukraine's security.
• Zelenskyy's meeting with Trump was reportedly more successful than a prior one.
• The Ukrainian president thanked Trump multiple times during the meeting.
• Details of security guarantees are still unclear after the discussions.

items.title: What to know about congressional redistricting efforts in California, Texas and elsewhere
items.standfirst: Democratic lawmakers are returning to Texas after a standoff over a controversial GOP redistricting plan. CBS News correspondent Nidia Cavazos has more on the redistricting push.
items.content: Democratic lawmakers are returning to Texas after a standoff over a controversial GOP redistricting plan. CBS News correspondent Nidia Cavazos has more on the redistricting push.

items.title: Democrats return to Texas after walkout to block redistricting effort
items.standfirst: Dozens of Democratic lawmakers who left Texas to block a controversial redistricting effort ended their two-week standoff on Monday, allowing progress on a new electoral map backed by Republican President Donald Trump. Their return gives the Texas House the quorum needed to move forward with approving a map that adds five new congressional districts likely to favour Republicans ahead of the 2026 midterm elections.
items.content: Dozens of Democratic lawmakers who left Texas to block a controversial redistricting effort ended their two-week standoff on Monday, allowing progress on a new electoral map backed by Republican President Donald Trump. Their return gives the Texas House the quorum needed to move forward with approving a map that adds five new congressional districts likely to favour Republicans ahead of the 2026 midterm elections.

items.title: Texas Democrats ending two-week walkout over gerrymandered US GOP House map
items.standfirst: California Democrats have advanced countereffort to redraw their congressional boundaries, against Trump's push.
items.content: California Democrats have advanced countereffort to redraw their congressional boundaries, against Trump's push.

items.title: Texas Democrats have returned home, ending redistricting standoff
items.standfirst: The Democrats will each be escorted by law enforcement officers to ensure they return Wednesday, as the state GOP prepares to pass a new congressional map.
items.content: Texas Democrats who left the state to stymie Republicans over redistricting have returned to Austin, ending a two-week standoff over President Donald Trump's plan to carve out five new GOP congressional seats. Their return to the state means the Texas House now has the sufficient number of legislators needed to pass a new map benefiting the GOP. Democrats had used the gambit to stall legislative business and bring national attention to Republicans’ decision to pursue off-cycle redistricting ahead of the midterms. In a statement, the Texas House Democratic Caucus said that members returned on Monday morning “to launch the next phase in their fight against the racist gerrymander that provoked a weeks-long standoff with Governor [Greg] Abbott and President Trump.” The drama in Texas set off a national redistricting battle, most prominently with California Gov. Gavin Newsom vowing to retaliate against Texas Republicans by extracting an equal number of Democratic-leaning districts from California’s congressional map. Trump has also been pushing to take his redistricting plan to other Republican-led states, like Indiana and Missouri. After Democrats returned to the state capitol, the House gaveled into session Monday afternoon with enough members to make quorum and conduct official business for the first time in weeks. The map and other legislation now heads to committees before the session resumes Wednesday. That prompted one more public show of force from the GOP: House Speaker Dustin Burrows on Monday assigned state law enforcement officers to escort the returned Democrats over the next two days, ensuring they come back to Austin on Wednesday. Texas Republican leaders had previously authorized Department of Public Safety officers to canvass the state and stationed them outside lawmakers' homes while they were outside the state. Texas Democrats debated how long to stay away from the state, but ultimately laid out two conditions for their return: that the legislature end its first special session and that California lawmakers introduce their own map granting Democrats five more seats to counter Texas. Both of those occurred on Friday, prompting the Texas lawmakers to start returning home. By breaking quorum, the members racked up hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines. It also set off a legal fight brought by Abbott and Attorney General Ken Paxton, who sought to remove some of the Democrats from office. Aid for Central Texas flood victims was held up by the standoff. Republicans put redistricting first on the legislative calendar, ahead of disaster relief considerations — a move that Democrats called out as irresponsible. The GOP, in response, argued that Democrats were delaying that relief by remaining out of state. Abbott had promised to continue calling special sessions after the first one ended, beginning with a second one that began on Friday — a move that added to the pressure he and other GOP leaders exerted on Democrats to end their protest.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Texas Democrats ended a two-week walkout over congressional redistricting.
• Republicans are now able to pass a new electoral map in Texas.
• California is pushing to approve a new congressional map.
• The new map could add up to five Democratic seats in California.
• The Texas map is expected to favor Republicans in upcoming elections.

• The reduction is by a quarter, to $600 million.
• This reflects investor caution about China's tech scene.
• Qiming is an early investor in Xiaomi.

clusters.title: Brazil pushes back against U.S. probe on its trade practices
clusters.neutral_headline: Brazil Rejects US Probe into Trade Practices
bullet_summary: Reported by Reuters Top News, Bloomberg Technology

items.title: Brazil pushes back against U.S. probe on its trade practices
items.standfirst: The investigation is seen as an attempt to justify the 50% tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump on all Brazilian exports to the U.S., excluding some 700 items.
items.content: The investigation is seen as an attempt to justify the 50% tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump on all Brazilian exports to the U.S., excluding some 700 items.

items.title: Brazil Pushes Back Against US Probe Into Its Trade Practices
items.standfirst: Brazil is forcefully rejecting Washington’s allegations of unfair trade practices, describing an investigation launched by the US Trade Representative into the matter as an illegitimate use of unilateral US trade law.
items.content: Brazil is forcefully rejecting Washington’s allegations of unfair trade practices, describing an investigation launched by the US Trade Representative into the matter as an illegitimate use of unilateral US trade law.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Brazil is pushing back against a US trade investigation.
• The US Trade Representative launched the investigation.
• Brazil views the probe as illegitimate.
• The US imposed 50% tariffs on Brazilian exports.
• Some 700 items are excluded from the tariffs.

clusters.title: Deadly flooding wipes out villages in northwestern Pakistan
clusters.neutral_headline: Flooding in Pakistan Causes Deaths and Displacement
bullet_summary: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods
Reported by Al Jazeera, BBC World

items.title: Deadly flooding wipes out villages in northwestern Pakistan
items.standfirst: A new wave of flooding has swept through villages in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.
items.content: A new wave of flooding has swept through villages in Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.

items.title: More than 200 missing in flood-hit district in Pakistan, official says
items.standfirst: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods.
items.content: Hundreds are reported missing in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province as a result of devastating floods.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Deadly flooding has hit northwestern Pakistan.
• Villages in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province were wiped out.
• Hundreds of people are reported missing.
• The flooding is a new wave of destruction.
• The area is severely impacted by the disaster.

clusters.title: Myanmar to hold first general election since 2021 coup amid ongoing civil war
clusters.neutral_headline: Myanmar to Hold Election Amid Ongoing Civil War
bullet_summary: Reported by NPR News, BBC World

items.title: Myanmar to hold first general election since 2021 coup amid ongoing civil war
items.standfirst: With large parts of the country under opposition control amid an ongoing civil war, analysts warn that election logistics could prove challenging.
items.content: With large parts of the country under opposition control amid an ongoing civil war, analysts warn that election logistics could prove challenging.(Image credit: Thein Zaw/AP)

items.title: War-torn Myanmar to hold first general election since 2021 coup
items.standfirst: Critics have denounced the vote as a sham that will be used to entrench the military government's power.
items.content: Critics have denounced the vote as a sham that will be used to entrench the military government's power.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Myanmar will hold its first election since the 2021 coup.
• The country is experiencing an ongoing civil war.
• Large parts of the country are under opposition control.
• Analysts question the election's logistics.
• Critics call the vote a sham.
